mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: If this is what it sounds like when a new millennium goes pop, I'll take it.
This sensationally engineered promo film makes Justin Bieber look like a true force of nature.
On stage variously with Boyz II Men, Jaden Smith, Miley Cyrus, and Ludacris, Bieber carries himself like a squeaky-clean homeboy with an angelic voice. On him, swagger looks sweet.
It generally succeeds, too, thanks to a visually energetic approach by director Jon Chu that keeps all the obligatory backstage/onstage bits moving fluidly.
As much a legitimate documentary as it is a 3D concert film and teen girl squeal-delivery device, the film possesses surprising moments of candor on the toil of teenage superstardom.
It's a fluffy, mildly inspiring, celebration of the hero leading up to his big moment.
Equal parts biopic, concert film and pep rally, the movie's 105 minutes do a good job of conveying the pleasures of pop, courtesy of the very real talents of Justin Bieber.
The movie usefully, carefully, and cogently argues that Bieber is more than his hair. He is his hoodies. He is his pop-hooks. He is his many handlers.

Bieber's world - at least as edited for mass consumption - is a refreshingly wholesome universe, where a young superstar is good-natured and grateful, says grace before every meal, and spends all his free time on the tour bus tweeting. He also likes to hug, a lot.
Everyone involved in "Never Say Never" is working overtime to prove that he is, as one of them puts it, "just a regular kid who had a dream," while everything about the movie screams the opposite.
The film is a really entertaining look at the Bieber phenomenon; the music in Never Say Never is great and Bieber proves himself to be the real thing as a musician and performer.
Chu does his best to humanize his subject, showing him surrounded by devoted friends and family, and wringing much drama from an on-the-road vocal-cord strain.
It's definitely not hard to understand what the little girls see in Bieber, and this film delivers the goods. This one's for the fans, not the movie buffs.

What we do see is mom, dad, Braun, Usher, vocal coach Mama Jan Smith and the burgeoning Team Bieber claiming they only want the best for the boy as he goes through a punishing 84-date concert tour. Group hug.
Never works as a gum-snapper concert movie and does provide a glimpse into instant stardom in the Twitter generation.
It's a disappointment to see the teen pop star hop in a tour bus. This is a boy who should be traveling across rainbows on the back of a unicorn.
Strictly as a piece of filmmaking, Never Say Never is a bit of a mess.
3D or not, the film about the mop-topped Canadian - who turns 17 March 1 - doesn't let us get very close to "the talent."
Squeaky clean fun for the youngsters in the family. Everyone else hide.
The film slowly builds up to Justin's first appearance at Madison Square Garden, where his show sold out in 22 minutes.
The film's premise-that Bieber achieved his superstardom through years of hard work overcoming towering obstacles-is so ludicrously flawed that everything built upon it borders on self-parody.
It is draggily paced and lacks felicity of form; the 3-D is a rip-off and the songs are pap, save a snippet of Etta James singing "At Last" while Bieber's glossy fringe sways in slow-motion.

mc_user_reviews.text: Worst movie I've EVER watched. Seriously pay me $500 and I won't watch this garbage. I suppose this is where our society is, that we have to make  a "documentary" (and I use that term loosely), about an overly sub par musician.

Now, had this kid been homeless and then he got found, it'd be a bit more impressive. I guess the question is why is this story worth telling. It isn't but the people involved knew they'd make a lot, especially if it was in 3-D. Bieber is not that talented. Justin Bieber is nothing more than a hack on the pop music industry and an arrogant jerk in general. Tired of seeing the media promote and advertise this jerk. While pop music may not fade, the people eventually do until the next kid comes around.  Bieber is so "famous" because so many preteen people have this inane fantasy that he actually cares about them. All he cares about is the money, all the "industry" cares about is the money and the set that likes him has spending power.  The movie was made to cash in quick. But these things are mostly cyclical, and he'll fade away soon enough. Sadly, people like us get to be inundated with this garbage until the ride is over.  The only major fans he attracts are preteen people, who tend to be a very shallow audience and are easily impressionable to like whoever the pop star is.  The major problem is he will be not simply fade in their shallow minds, he will be replaced with another boy or boy band to annoy those of use with 6th grade and higher educations.  He's just another recyclable commodity like most of this teeny, pop idols. be replaced by another "farmed" individual that meets the current needs of the music industry today. People are attracted to these individuals(Can I really call them that though? Especially when they don't write their own music or lyrics...) Save your money and time on an actual movie.

I dont see why anyone would like this movie. It doesnt make any sense. The story of this guy is nothing special. Why should I (or anyone else) like this? I mean, the story of my life is better than this kid's. Same goes for my neighbour, my pregnant girlfriend, my half-wit step sister, my kindergarten teacher, my maid's maid, the kid who pees on my doorway everynight  etc etc. I mean why dont they produce a movie about these people? It would still beat this movie by far. Do the producers hate the audience and people in general. Do they have some kind of hatred towards humanity. Are they angry that man went to the moon, that america has a black president, that elvis is dead? Did god send them to punish us for our sins? Or do they have nothing better to do? To be honest, if i had a chance to reverse time and undo my regrets, not watching this movie would be at the top. I would rather go to jail than watch this ****. I would eat my beef raw than watch this ****. I would kiss a guy's ass(literally) than humiliate my self esteem by watching this. Hell, if i had to choose between this movie and a soaking my face in a pile of horse s**t on a plate, i would choose the tasty looking dish on the right.

A documentary about a sixteen-year-old? What had he done? Sang some songs and dated Selina Gomez? The entire movie is the kid rubbing all of his "talent" and money in the viewers face, then doing a show at the Garden that - surprise, surprise - gets sold out almost immediately. I thought the movie would've at least shown his rise to stardom from rock bottom, hence the title, but it was almost the exact opposite of that. If I knew the title was going to be that misleading I wouldn't of gone to see this stupid film. All it does is make you feel bad about your life, which is not nearly as good as Justin Bieber's. The title should be changed to "Justin Bieber: You'll Never Be As Rich As Me". At least it would've been accurately titled if that were the case.

Valentines Day: A day when couple lovingly embrace in happiness. This years Valentines Day was the day I was assaulted by a torture on the ears and of nausea. Why? I was dragged to see the Justin Beiber movie Let's get this straight: If you don't like Justin Beiber, theres a 95% chance you'll hate this film. If you're affected by Beiber fever, you'll lap this up like a cat with milk. As you can tell by the opening paragraph, I am not a fan. I don't have anything against Justin Beiber, its great he's come so far from performing on Youtube, but I am in no way a fan of his music, his voice just feels so autotuned. This film utterly feels pointless, it tells you the Beiber story, which you could read on Wikipedia for less money, but the film has an additional selling point: 3D! So basically, if you're too lazy to read Justin Beibers story, you can shell out money and watch it with the addition of interviews with annoying fans ("I think about him 99% of my life" says one fan), Baby Beibers footage and baby photos, highlights (I say that loosely) from his Madison Square Garden gig and Miley Cyrus IN 3D! Please, heed my warning. I suffered so you couldn't. Avoid

I wasn't a fan of Justin before watching this movie and would even make jokes about him so when my friend made me watch this is wasnt best pleased. However, the story of his life is so inspiring and interesting. I never knew that he lived in poverty and how hard he really had it to make it to the top. He didnt go looking for fame, fame found him through his raw talent. The film begins telling the story of his early life and builds up to the moment he plays his sold out madison square garden concert. I find him to be a real charming down to earth humble kid (who happens to now be 18). His new album 'Believe' is one of the best albums ive bought in a long time and I will now proudly say at 22 years of age, I am a fan. The kid has never done anything wrong, only followed his dream which is protrayed well throught the movie.

I couldn't even do that due to utter useless chants and shouting from young girls. Even my friend was a bit ashamed. Why ? Just why ?? How the heck the critics kept it over 50 ! Aren't they human beings ?!

It all started when I was 7 years old. My parents gave me a CD player and a copy of Justin Bieber - Baby for christmas. I fell in love with it the moment I booted up the CD player. The composition, the arrangement, the talent! It overwhelmed my young mind. I listened it for hours on end, memorizing each sentence, each modulation, each note of the melody, every single drum beat. It was the only thing I did, I stopped going outside and playing with my friends, for Justin Bieber was the only friend I needed. Eventually I became unsatisfied, I needed a new Justin Bieber single to fuel my addiction. My prayers were answered with the release of Never say Never. My parents refused to buy it for me. They believed I was too obsessed with the first one and knew that buying the latest one would only make my obsession worse. This devestated me. I NEEDED that single, I felt like an alcoholic going through withdrawl. I lost all of my spirit, I had trouble sleeping at night, and sometimes I would experience hallucinations where Justin was in the room with me. I begged my parents every day, but they wouldn't budge. I felt I had lost the will to live. Thankfully, I got the single. I aquired it the same way every kid got something that they wanted but their parents wouldn't buy for them, Grandma. I was overjoyed, finally I could experience the masterpiece that is known as Justin Bieber - Never say Never. This time he was accompanied by Jaden Smith! I was delighted. I listened to this single, and memorised it like I had the original. By now I had lost contact with society, I didn't talk to anybody at school, I had no friends, and I never left the house. This didn't bother me though, in fact I preferred it that way. Just as I started to get bored of that single, Boyfriend came out. My obsession had hit an all-time high, I was amazed at the quality of that single. We now had Justin Bieber, Lucardis and Jaden Smith. They were my friends, or "The Gang" as I called them. My parents were scared of me now. If they tried to take the music away from me, I would throw a tantrum and break things until they gave it back. No amount of reasoning, counseling, or Native American rituals could change me, because by now Justin Bieber had was not just an obsession, but a lifestyle. I lived and breathed Justin Bieber. But then came the dark days, no Justin Bieber singles were coming out. RBMG labels had stopped supporting Justin Bieber, and had launched Korean PSY. I didn't have his single Gangnam Style, but that didn't matter. No new Justin Bieber singles were coming out. There were rumors, but the only one that ever turned out to be true was All That Matters. I saw it as an abomination, how could RBMG do this to Justin Bieber? After several years I had just about given up. I would often times cry myself to sleep, believing that RBMG had given up on the teenage idol that I had come to adore. I wrote my own stories about Bieber, fanfictions about him having a relationship with Jaden Smith, but they weren't enough. But then it happened. I was at the grocery store with my mother, when I saw it: A magazine with a picture of a new model of DVD player plastered right on the cover. I begged my mom to buy it for me, and she did, relieved that I wanted something that wasn't Justin Bieber related, or so she thought. I read the articles about the upcoming DVD player, and then I saw what I have been wanting to see for years, a new Justin Bieber item was in the works, and it was full-lenght MOVIE too! My life had a purpose again. When the day finally came, I was there. I was the first in line, I had convinced poor old Grandma to buy it for me, and I made sure I got a copy of Justin Bieber - Never say Never. If the singles on the CD's amazed me, Never say Never left me speechless. The imagery was such good quality, the story so deep, the music blew me away. This was the way Justin Bieber was meant to be. It rekindled the fire that had laid dormant in me that is Justin Bieber. I wrote more fanfiction, I made my own fancharacters and I even shipped them. Then I realized something, Justin Bieber wasn't just a teen idol on TV, He was a part of me. I became one with Justin Bieber. If you want to be like me and know what truly matters in life, I fully recommend listening to Justin Bieber. Justin Bieber is more than just a teen idol pop star, Justin Bieber is a way of life.

Music brings joy.  This film shows a remarkably gifted toddler with a pronounced gift for music-making, who pursues his passion for musical performance with determination, passion, grit and optimism.  In the process, he becomes a pied piper to mostly young girls, who fawn over his boyish charm and impossibly cute hair.  But at bottom, he is a real musician, and a damned good one.  The skillfully edited film shows the magnitude of joy that music can bring, even when accompanied by pop boy band production values.  I don't much like pop music, and I really don't like young pop stars who are highly produced and thrust into media by the entertainment industry.  But I loved this movie, and came away really liking and admiring Justin Bieber.

As a parent, I was happy to have her watch this movie -- it's clean, inspirational & has a good message for kids.  Those of you (most) who hated it probably shouldn't have bothered watching it in the first place. In fact, I wonder if any of the very low scores even watched it and aren't just trying to get the user score down. That would be a shame.

I went with my 12 yr old daughter, her friend & mom to see "Never Say Never" premier. We did enjoy the movie. It not only showed Justin's rise to stardom but his mother's sacrfices she made to make sure, as a single young mother, he was brought up with values and respect. His grandparents were normal, very much like my daughters, in the respect they kept him grounded. He had to clean his room before he could go out with his friends-didn't matter that he was JUSTIN BEIBER. His grandfather brought me to tears, talking of letting them go, Justin & his mom, to Atlanta to do recordings & start his singing career. I did wonder what Justin's father's intentions really were, never around in any pictures while he was growing up past a few months old...all the credit should go to his mom, grandparents & his crew who loves & adores him. I do wish it would have stayed with him in it's entirety of his songs but his journey thus far was portrayed very nicely. Loved the hair wisp & the part about texting.

Got exactly what I expected, a good story about a kid who came from nothing and now is a star.  Kid has real talent and isn't just another pop singer. Interesting how social media can now make just about anyone a star.
